On Wed, Jan 4, 2012 at 12:54 PM, Jan Algermissen <jan.algermissen@...
> wrote:

> **
>
>
>
> On Jan 4, 2012, at 1:18 PM, Mike Kelly wrote:
>
> > I wasn't saying there
> > is anything actually 'wrong' with forms, just that introducing them to
> > a machine app is (for the time being) a costly and mostly fruitless
> > effort - it increases the complexity of consuming the application (by
> > adding a requirement to understand form processing rules) without
> > delivering much by way of improving evolvability - it doesn't bring
> > much to the table, and many clients will either get it wrong or hack
> > around it anyway. This may well improve in the future but right now it
> > doesn't seem like a good option from the practical, cost-benefit point
> > of view (not the architecturally pure one).
>
> A benefit of forms is that they can provide data to include in the
> corresponding submission that needs not or must not (due to volatility) be
> remembered by the client.
>
> An example would be the current price of an item. Instead of constructing
> an order and including a remembered price, the current price can be right
> in the form for the client to review and then put into the submission
> request.
>
>
This is possible without forms by making the carried values a part of the
necessary representations and making the client behaviour (carrying the
value) part of the 'domain application protocol'. The difference with forms
is that the information that the client can potentially carry is arbitrary
with forms as far as the client is concerned, and the control of the
resultant request is completely in the hands of the server presenting the
initial form.

There is a pretty serious security implication of this approach, in that
the integrity of the client's request is lost to the server which in many
cases will belong to an external organisation. I imagine this would raise
security concerns about how far (if at all) such a mechanism should be
allowed to go; e.g. requiring a same-domain policy or removing the ability
for additional, arbitrary inputs to be injected into the resulting request.
These sorts of measures would make a big dent in the benefits of taking the
form approach. If half of your clients were ok with that, and the other
half weren't - could you really make significant changes to those forms
(e.g. changing the domain or adding in another field) and be confident
about the risks?

Cheers,
Mike

--0015174bf1c2971fad04b5b3cda2
